The Ashes Diary: Conga lines, cookie monsters and cricket

06/08/2013

In the wake of England retaining the Ashes, Beth Jakubowski brings us her diary from the third day of the Old Trafford test where Kevin Pietersen fought back against Australia's huge first innings total

Image by

By undefined undefined

At 5:00pm on the 5th of August 2013 the umpires went to the Australian and English dressing rooms to inform them that play had been abandoned for the day. Rain had been bombarding Old Trafford for nearly two hours and the dark clouds surrounding the ground were only looking more ominous. At 5:00pm on the 5th of August, England officially retained the Ashes. It was hardly the way English fans would have wanted that announcement to happen. It was a tinny voice on the Old Trafford tannoy system accompanied by a fairly understated sign on the big screen that informed the country that their cricket team had retained the Ashes for a third series in a row. It really deserved a bigger occasion. Contrary to the griping and moaning of pundits and fans alike following the announcement, England did not retain the Ashes because of rain. England retained the Ashes because they went into the third test already two nil up. England won the Ashes because they have been the better team over the three tests that have already been played. The Saturday of an Ashes test match is always a special occasion, but there was a certain buzz around the ground when I took my seat to see if England could fight back against Australia's mammoth 527-7 declared. There was nervous anticipation around the ground and a sense of cautious optimism. For many fans they have seen England fail time and time again against the old enemy. I'm part of a fortunate generation of English fans who have grown up watching the likes of Michael Vaughan and Andrew Strauss lead England to glory home and away. You certainly can't blame the intrinsic sense of pessimism that most people have when they watch England play. The start of play was awe inspiring. Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott emerged from the dressing room to a rousing chorus of 'Jerusalem'. It sent shivers down my spine. A feeling began to grow amongst the crowd that anything was possible, and as the crowd began to find their voices, Alastair Cook took guard. Despite the optimistic start to the day's play things went downhill very rapidly. The hosts lost Jonathan Trott for 5 and suddenly England were three wickets down and staring down the barrel of a huge first inning deficit or worse, enduring the follow on. Enter Kevin Pietersen. Pietersen was raucously cheered to the crease by the Old Trafford faithful. It struck me then that despite Pietersen's rocky relationship with the ECB and at times, his own teammates, the fans have always found room in their cricket loving hearts for him. Watching England bat live is a strange experience. You're constantly on tender hooks and unable to truly settle and enjoy the cricket. There's always a deep seated fear that the next ball will be England's undoing. Thankfully, the crowd find various witty and amusing ways to entertain themselves. In our section of the stand, that was incidentally right next to the England dressing room, we had rather a large amount of Aussie fans. Cue the chants. 'Stand UP if you're two nil UP, stand UP if you're two nil UP!' quickly became a fan favourite. The Aussie's, gallantly dressed as convicts, deserve a lot of credit for taking the abuse so well. As the day wore on the beer began to flow freely - which is when a group of lads next to me decided to take on the forbidden yet thrilling challenge of creating a 'beer snake'. In the true spirit of the Barmy Army, they thought it was only fair that the rest of the stand be invited to join in their quest. One chap started to weave his way through the crowd, only stumbling occasionally, demanding that we 'feed the snake'. We were only too happy to oblige. Tragedy struck not long before lunch. The beer snake was confiscated by stewards to a chorus of boo's from the crowd. Things were in danger of turning hostile if it wasn't for a man dressed as Superman declaring that we help him find 'Wally'. Sure enough, moments later a poor fellow dressed as Where's Wally emerged from the crowd looking rather bewildered. While all this was going on the beer snake creators had somehow stealthily managed to reclaim the confiscated snake in a dazzling display of drunken ingenuity. All the while the Cookie Monster was dancing with Minnie Mouse and a conga line of policemen headed by Batman and Robin were parading around the temporary stand. Amongst the insanity and madness of a Saturday at Old Trafford Kevin Pietersen was launching the ball into the pavilion and Ian Bell was classily accumulating yet more runs with a deft flick to mid off. We were lulled into a false sense of security and foolishly began to parade the beer snake around the stand to the ever increasing chant of 'SNAKE, SNAKE, SNAKE, SNAKE!' Batman even found time to assist the stewards with one punter who perhaps had one too many. Robin was nowhere to be found. One of my personal highlights of the day was courtesy of an Aussie. Peter Siddle is an Australian player I genuinely admire; he has a huge heart and comes across as a bloke who is giving his absolute all for his country. He was fielding at the boundary when I realised the crowd were good naturedly making 'beep, beep, beep' noises every time he stepped backwards. Siddle took the banter with great humour, turning round and laughing with the crowd and generally enjoying his experience at Old Trafford. It was a lovely moment that showed despite the high intensity of the Ashes, there is no true resentment amongst the fans or the players. It showed cricket in the very best light. But all too soon our attention was turned back to what was happening in the middle. Pietersen was crawling his way through the eighties and all of a sudden I was quite literally on the edge of my seat and my heart was thumping uncomfortably in my chest. The crowd grew unnaturally quiet as he hovered in the nineties. Then, suddenly, the bubble of pressure burst and the crowd rose to their feet in sheer relief and unadulterated joy to celebrate Pietersen's hundred. It was an unusual century from Pietersen, it was measured and careful and lacked the assuredness of his past knocks. But it was one that England desperately needed and in the grand scheme of the match, it was vital. Alastair Cook admitted the drawn test was an anti-climax and of course, they would have wanted it to have happened another way, they would have wanted to win the test. But at the end of the day the urn is staying where it belongs. England must now go on and win the series in emphatic style to make up for all those years of Australian dominance. For all the hi-jinks, beer snakes and superheroes at Old Trafford on Saturday the real spectacle was the cricket. Although the follow on was worryingly imminent, I walked out of the ground in good spirits, I had seen runs, wickets and spectacular fielding. I had seen a proper day of test cricket.
